div1.p: Mason refutes the assertion that he used mosquitoes sent by Ames in his experiments, and that the mosquitoes Ames did send were worthless specimens. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Charles F. Mason to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 18, 1907
div1.opener:
COPY
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
a
To Major J.R. Kean,
February 18, 1907.
My dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Replying further to your letter of the fourteenth in-
stant, Assistant Surgeon Carroll states that “Doctor Ames was
never the subject of any attempt at experimental innoculation by
the Army Yellow Fever Board. He was born and graduated in medi-
cine at New Orleans and the very fact, as stated by Dr. Berry,
that Doctor Ames was at that time regarded as a yellow fever ex-
pert and an immune would preclude the idea of using him for any
such purpose. The truth is that Doctor Ames was totally unaware
of the first mosquito innoculations until the results were being
compiled two months later, for publication.” Doctor Ames was,
however, in charge of Camp Lazear, the experimental yellow fever
camp.

On account of his experience with yellow fever Dr. Ames
was detailed for duty in Texas during the yellow fever outbreak
there in 1903; in 1905 when yellow fever occurred in New Orleans
he was in that city on leave, and upon his own urgent request was
detailed for duty at Jackson Barracks as assistant to the Surgeon,
Lieutenant William L. Little. In neither epidemic did the advice
not to remove the troops originate with Dr. Ames.

In 1903 the Acting Chief Surgeon of the Department of
Texas made the original recommendation, and in 1905, it was made
by the Acting Surgeon General of the Army.

In regard to Dr. Berry's statement concerning the in-
-2-
fected mosquito incident, Dr. Carroll says: “The last sentence in
the fifth paragraph of Doctor Berry's letter clearly implies,
without saying so, that the mosquitoes collected by Dr. Ames were
used by me in showing that the so-called Myxococcidium stegomyia
was neither an animal parasite nor the parasite of yellow fever.
My results in this connection were embodied in a paper presented
at the meeting of the American Public Health Association in Wash-
ington, October 26th to 30th, 1903, and published in the Journal
of the American Medical Association, November 28, 1903. The rec-
ords of this laboratory show that the first lot of mosquitoes re-
ceived from Doctor Ames at Laredo arrived at this laboratory No-
vember 27, 1903; it is therefore absolutely impossible that they
could have been used for the purpose stated, indeed these insects
were not sectioned until some months later and were then found to
be worthless. The demonstration was actually made from infected
mosquitoes preserved chiefly by myself in Havana and from non-in-
fected mosquitoes raised from eggs in Washington, with others re-
ceived through Doctor O. L. Howard and Doctor Edmond Souchon, to
both of whom acknowledgements are made in my paper mentioned above.”
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Sgd) Chas. F. Mason, Major, Surgeon, U. S. Army.
VE
